head.title: With Liberty and 210 Horsepower for All

hedline.hl1: With Liberty and 210 Horsepower for All

block.p: Introduced on Wednesday: Jeep Liberty midsize sport utility vehicle
Is it real? Yes. The replacement for the Jeep Liberty has been long-awaited. Awaited, for some, since the vehicle was first introduced in 2002.
Introduced on Wednesday: Jeep Liberty midsize sport utility vehicle
Is it real? Yes. The replacement for the Jeep Liberty has been long-awaited. Awaited, for some, since the vehicle was first introduced in 2002.
What's the point? The original Liberty was homely, slow and heavy, but it became a minor hit for Jeep because it caught on with female buyers looking for a soft-offroader with a macho look.

What they said: "The all-new 2008 Jeep Liberty stands out from the competition by offering customers classic Jeep design, two four-wheel-drive systems, refined on-road ride and handling, cargo and utility, as well as features that are not typically found on vehicles in the mid-size S.U.V. segment," said George Murphy, senior vice president for global marketing of the Chrysler Group.

What they didn't say: As the outgoing Liberty proved, Jeep fans are willing to overlook a few warts. Since the new one is easier on the eyes, a bit more fuel-efficient and has a few new convenience features, it should continue to appeal to its soft-core demographic.

What makes it tick? The best and worst of past Liberty engines have been discontinued; namely the much sought-after diesel and the anemic four-cylinders; now the only choice is a 210-horsepower V-6, with a six-speed manual or a four-speed automatic.
How much, how soon? At dealerships in the third quarter of 2007, priced in line with the outgoing model, which started at $21,600.
How's it look? The '08 Liberty's more angular styling and new squared-off headlights give it more of a family resemblance, and evoke another Jeep cult classic: the Cherokee.
